pros: Insurance was the only pro

Expected one person to handle 100+ phone calls a day and document all immediately as well as other receptionist duties with no assistance from other staff members. Refused to allow me to leave early to go to urgent care/dr appointment for immediate medical issues due to me being new. Did not give me full explanation for why I was let go, I was eligible to transfer but the company did not allow it. Manager was extremely kind upon hiring but quickly became extremely rude and condescending. The doctor repeatedly ignored phone calls ans medication requests which increased number of phone calls per day.

review_title: Love the hospital but not the job
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Cincinnati, OH
pros: I had a fantastic manager at Christ and she really cared about me as a PCA but also as a person. I learned a lot and the training for the job was thorough.
cons: As a PCA you are kind of thrown around by some higher ups whether that be other nurses, doctors, or whoever is in charge. It can be frustrating because you are there to do everything for your patient that is under the scope of basic care. So anytime the patient calls out, you are their point of contact. Now when you have 10 patients constantly needing help - this leads to a very busy shift. On days where I didn’t receive help from nurses or fellow PCAs I had to skip my lunch break. That part of the job was probably the worst part. The work isn’t glamorous by any means but that kind of comes with the territory of being a PCA.

job_title: RN Care Manager in Cincinnati, OH

cons: Benefits, Micro-managing, no growth, PTO

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Ratios are pretty good. I’m on an ICU stepdown/CT surgery/telemetry floor and ratios are 1:4 on days, 1:5 on nights max. Charge can have 1-2 patients but it is avoided if possible. You always have a PCA to help with patient care and get vitals, etc. You have respiratory therapists to give breathing treatments, IV therapy to place your IVs and phlebotomy to draw your labs. Christ also has a STAT team to respond if you feel your patient is deteriorating.
cons:
The pay isn’t as good as other healthcare systems.
You have to go get your own admits from the ED and PACU.
There is no union.
You have to work every third weekend and there is 12 hours of on call per schedule period.

job_title: Performance Improvement Nurse in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Friendly coworkers, transparent management team
cons: Insurance is much more expensive

job_title: PRN Occupational Therapist in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
Co-workers are friendly
PRN get to choose the weekend days they want to work first before full time staff fill in.
PRN do not have to work holidays unless you ask management and really want to work the shift to help out.
If you are sick or have an emergency and are not able to work your shift, you do not have to make up that shift at any other time. However, it looks bad and the schedule does rely on you to be there. 
If you have a problem with scheduling management is willing to work with you.
cons:
High requirement for PRN status, 3 weekend days a month. No option to drop down unless you want a decrease in pay. Lowest paying PRN rate in the area, however, working 3 weekend days a month does add up to a good salary.
PRN are required to clock in and out of every shift and you do not typically get called off on the weekends if scheduling or census is low. You are the last to be called off. Expect to be there every shift you commit to. It is difficult to switch shifts unless you have a coworker that is willing to switch.
You need to be aware that your schedule will not just be acute care. Christ has a rehab department and you will likely be trained to work on the unit and be a rehab therapist as well.
You do not know what your schedule will look like on a weekend. Be prepared to be flexible upon arrival. Do not be late.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Helping patients, great clinical staff.
cons: On-call is over used, plan on working those days. They "share" you to other floors often, it's like being at a different job because each floor is run, and managed differently. They can't keep staff. Money is not the only issue, most people will turn down extra pay for picking up hours. This is just scaping the surface. I'm sure most hospitals are having problems right now. To just simply state that "we appreciate you" on random wall monitors does not make up for taking away your vacation, and cutting of some of your benefits for over 6 months. I hope they and the rest of the country's health care figure things out, because I would be scared to go to a hospital right now.

pros: Improved patient satisfaction due to improving technological advancements within Epic software sytems
cons:
As of lately there has been major changes in upper administration and lack thereof.  The after effect is creating tumultuous affects for teams specifically within IT.  Company culture is non-existent and the focus is on $$$.  

There is zero engagement with management in developing their teams which is HUGE when it comes to day to day work satisfaction. Sadly, I have seen this decline over the past three years. If they don't make changes they will be losing a huge pool of skilled talent.

pros: The only thing I can say that is a pro is that some of the co-workers were mature and respectful. And the fact that they pay a descent wage. Notice I say descent.
cons: I worked as a material maintenance in the Central Service Dept. Management was very poor and easily swayed; blatantly showing favoritism. The other hospitals in the area are paying somewhere around $5 more per hour to do the same thing. Expensive insurance! Numerous people have been let go because of being injured on the job. Yet the department will say they need to relist the position because the person injured is no longer able to do that job. They do not look for other positions within the hospital to place the person.

pros: Some of the best co workers I have ever had on 7 South.  Extremely helpful and friendly PCAs. RNs treat PCAs very well. Great managers who are very supportive of staff and are extremely helpful and understanding in working around school schedules for PCAs. If you are in nursing school and want to work as a PCA to learn and get experience I highly recommend working on 7S in particular.
cons: Often short staffed and with high acuity.
